name: Complete 1.e4 Repertoire for White
description: A comprehensive repertoire for White starting with 1.e4, covering responses to the Petrov, Scandinavian, French, and more.
author: IM Andras Toth & Community

lines.name: Scandinavian: Valencian Variation
lines.description: The Scandinavian is a great opening for the active Black player. Having the queen out early is contrary to opening principles, however the Scandinavian is one notable exception to this rule. White tries to gain extra tempi by attacking the Black queen.
lines.analysis: White has a strong attacking position.

lines.name: Scandinavian: Richter Variation (Portuguese Gambit)
lines.description: In the Portuguese Gambit, Black elects to play Nf6 instead of the more traditional Qxd5. White should get on with their usual agenda (center and development), instead of trying to keep the d5-pawn.
lines.analysis: White has a dominant position with fabulous attacking prospects.

lines.name: Scandinavian: Main Line, Mieses Variation
lines.description: The main line of the Scandinavian where Black plays 3...Qa5. Our plan is to challenge the pinned knight and gain space on the kingside.
lines.analysis: The black bishop on g6 is experiencing extreme discomfort.

lines.name: Caro-Kann: Bronstein-Larsen Variation
lines.description: After Black plays 5...gxf6, the pawn chain is broken and kingside castling is risky due to the semi-open g-file. Our plan involves knight maneuvers and a central d4-d5 break.
lines.analysis: White has a tremendous attacking position, whilst the black pawn structure also offers multiple strategic targets, in particular, the weak pawns and the f5-outpost.

lines.name: Caro-Kann: Karpov Variation Trap
lines.description: The Karpov Variation (4...Nd7) is solid, but we can reply with the unorthodox 5.Ng5! to generate tactical opportunities on the light squares, in particular f7 and e6.
lines.analysis: A stunning geometrical motif that decides the game. The queen is lost!

lines.name: Caro-Kann: Classical, Lobron System
lines.description: The Caro-Kann is known for its reliable, sturdy layout. Against the Classical variation (4...Bf5), we will play the Lobron System with h4-h5 to gain space and prepare a kingside attack.
lines.analysis: With Black having committed to opposite side castling, we adjust our plans! This counter-intuitive knight move prepares a major assault on the kingside.

lines.name: Caro-Kann: Von Hennig Gambit
lines.description: An aggressive pawn gambit (4.Bc4 and 5.f3) to seize a large pawn center and get the opponent out of their theoretical knowledge.

lines.name: Petrov Defense: Main Line (Improved)
lines.description: The Petroff Defense is one of the most popular openings of our time. We will play the most principled move, 3.Nxe5, to eliminate the important e5-pawn instantly.
lines.analysis: White has the upper hand with a double attack on the a7 and g7 pawns.

lines.name: Petrov: Main Line - 5.Nc3
lines.description: The most popular and principled response. The e5-pawn is a vital central asset and we eliminate it instantly, then develop with Nc3 to trade knights and open the d-file for our queen and bishop.
lines.analysis: White has the upper hand with a double attack on the a7 and g7 pawns.

lines.name: Petrov: Cochrane Gambit - 4.Nxf7!!
lines.description: A sharp knight sacrifice for two pawns and complete exposure of Black's king. This is extremely dangerous in practical play - most games end decisively, rarely in draws.
lines.analysis: A complex position where White maintains pressure.

lines.name: Petrov: Steinitz Variation - 3.d4
lines.description: A sharp, modern variation where both players plant their knights in advanced positions. Exchanges often occur to avoid a single piece becoming too powerful.
lines.analysis: The position is roughly equal, with dynamic chances for both sides.

lines.name: Petrov: Three Knights Alternative - 3.Nc3
lines.description: A sound alternative to avoid the sharpest Petrov lines. If Black plays 3...Nc6, we transpose to the Four Knights Game. If Black plays 3...Bb4, we keep the game active.
lines.analysis: From here, Black can play 3...Nc6, transposing to the Four Knights, or play 3...Bb4 to maintain a unique position.
